body: @winstywang does this issue be fixed?
Currently you can use CSV iterator. I am working on SFrame iter (https://github.com/dato-code/SFrame), which will be avaliable soon.
@antinucleon Thank you! A problem is that I didn't find the CSVIter example's raw data.
The raw data for the iterator is a csv file
I see, will try this out. Thanks.
NDArrayIter does work on numpy memory maps. I am using it with multiple inputs, each ~250G in size.

You can use infer_shape: https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.Symbol.infer_shape

eg:

```
data = mx.sym.Variable("data")
fc = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=data, num_hidden=256)

arg_shape, output_shape, aux_shape = fc.infer_shape(data=(1, 128))
```

@jmschrei  Thanks, I will try it latter.

hi, @antinucleon . I try your suggestion to use CSV iterator to represent the input data.
So I prepare two csv files data.csv, label.csv for data, and label, respectively.

When I try to feed csv iterator to model, it keeps saying that, "Data CSV's row is smaller than the number of rows in label_csv". What is this problem, how to fix it?

format in data.csv is 1d vector each row.
format in label is 0 or 1 each row.
and this two csv files has same rows.

1, Please make sure there is no header in the csv
2. sample:

```
batch_size = 128
num_fea = 5
data_train = mx.io.CSVIter(data_csv="./train-data.csv", data_shape=(num_fea,),
                           label_csv="./train-stytole.csv", label_shape=(2,),
                           batch_size=batch_size)
```

the label csv is like

```
0,1\n
1,0\n
```

Thanks for reply, @antinucleon !

yes, there is not header in the csv.
And I do the same way with your provided. 

I upload my files, could you help to take a look? They are only 10 rows used to test the functionality.

label file, [ll.txt](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/73096/ll.txt)
training data file, [tt.txt](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/files/73097/tt.txt)

I test with the alexnet, win7, infiniband 
local:                               195samples/s (1pc with 1gpu)                 613(1pc with 4gpu)
local_allreduce_cpu:       319samples/s(up on)                              1240samples/s(up on)
dist_sync                         300(2pc with 2gpu)                                 1200(2pc with 8gpu)

one machine two cpu with 8 gpu on two sides is similar with 4gpu on the same side
@mli  is it normal?  
and I want to know How many cluster systems are supported in theory with mxnet?

I have reviewed the codes. The codes are generally good. One major issue is that it uses different size for training. Actually, we can randomly crop the input to a fixed size instead. It will speed up the training significantly, and make the codes shorter and cleaner.
@piiswrong Thank you!
Hi, I have tried openblas, and fixed the problem. Thank you

@qiaohaijun I guess it is mainly due to optimizer, currently it doesn't distinguish the type of parameters, and add decay to both weight and bias and the parameters of bn. We are still on the way to a clean solution.
@winstywang , thanks, i have answered some corresponding review, and i'll fix the cut_off_size bug first.
seems it's the same with  #967
why you think they should be equal in theory?

Thank you very much for your swift response @thirdwing  . I do feel like I'm getting further with your help now, but I'm not quite there yet. I think I'm lacking some basic knowledge of installing packages this way. I have described in detail what I have done so far, and note that some of the information may be completely redundant but I am unsure as to what I am doing wrong.

**Create `R-package/inst/libs/x64` folder - SUCCESS**
(1) I have done what you said and created a folder called `R-package/inst/libs/x64`   (in some arbitrary location I assumed)

**Copy .dll files into `R-package/inst/libs/x64`**
(2) I have copied a bunch of .dll files into the `R-package/inst/libs/x64` folder. I'm unsure whether I have chosen the correct ones. 
  Compared to the [mxnet_0.5.zip](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dmlc/drat/gh-pages/bin/windows/contrib/3.2/mxnet_0.5.zip) file, and the folder MXNET/libs/x64:
- I have the same .dll files. (Noted that the libmxnet.dll I copied is twice the size of the pre-built package file, because it is now the GPU version I'm guessing.)
- I have also copied 4 extra .dll files from the cudart and cudnn folders, namely,
  - cublas64_75.dll
  - cudart64_75.dll
  - cudnn64_4.dll
  - curand64_75.dll

I simply assumed I needed those .dll files as well, I hope I'm right about that.

**Create/build `R-package/inst/include` folder**
(3) I have created the `R-package/inst/include` folder and the folders in `mxnet/nocudnn/include`. Remember, I used the files from here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases/download/weekly_binary_build/20151209_win64_gpu.7z

So now, `R-package/inst/include` contains 3 subfolders, namely:
- dmlc
- mshadow (unsure about whether I need this one)
- mxnet

**Attempt to use R CMD INSTALL**
If I run `R CMD INSTALL R-package` at this point, I get `Warning: invalid package 'R-package`.

I figured, I first need to run `R CMD build --no-build-vignettes R-package`, as in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/Makefile#L199
(Unsure about the `--no-build-vignettes` part though, I'm unsure of what it does and also tried the command without that argument.)

If I do try to run `R CMD build --no-build-vignettes R-package` now I get the Error that there is no DESCRIPTION file. Specifically I get:
- checking for file 'R-package/DESCRIPTION' ... NO

**The ways I tried to fix it**
So, naturally I copied the DESCRIPTION, INDEX, LICENSE etc. files from [mxnet_0.5.zip](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dmlc/drat/gh-pages/bin/windows/contrib/3.2/mxnet_0.5.zip) into `R-package/` and tried running the command again.

Now, it does seem like if I re-run `R CMD build --no-build-vignettes R-package` that this made some progress. This is the output:
    \* checking for file 'R-package/DESCRIPTION' ... OK
    \* preparing 'mxnet':
    \* checking DESCRIPTION meta-information ... OK
    ERROR
   computing Rd index failed

The R warnings it returned were: `Warning in file(con, "r"): cannot open file 'man'`
I wouldn't know where I should've added a file called 'man', so I am lost here.

I feel like I missed something trivial and much of the information I gave above may be redundant.

**EDIT: Some extra output info**

I tried running `R CMD INSTALL R-package` without the whole `R CMD build` step. After I added the DESCRIPTION, INDEX, LICENSE etc. files like I described above, I get the following output:
- installing to library 'D:/Program files/R-3.1.2/li
- installing _binary_ package 'mxnet' ...
  cp: unknown option -- )
  Try `/usr/bin/cp --help' for more information.
  Warning: running command 'cp -R . "D:/Program files/R-3.1.2/library/mxnet" || (tar cd - .| (cd "D:/Program files/R-3.1.2/library/mxnet && tar -xf -))' had status 1
  ERROR: installing binary package failed
- removing 'D:/Program files/R-3.1.2/library/mxnet'

This does not help me personally, but it might be a known error to someone else.
The shape here should be consistent with what `provide_data` and `provide_label` return.

I think HDF5 data iter support should be useful. Though introducing an extra dependency on libhdf5 is not desired, we can implement it in the front-end side as most languages have mature 3rd party HDF5 support.

I think the reason I didn't use std::function is because when the call back takes more than 1 argument, std:function doesn't work. Could you verify if it's still the case?
And there shouldn't be a difference between std::function and C function PTR, because the c_api interface is pure C and the pointer passed in have to be pure C anyway.

mxnet is not deterministic due to various in-determinism in dependencies. Even two runs on the same GPU are not guaranteed to give identical results. 0.1% sounds like a reasonable difference caused by randomness.
The problem was due to indeterminism in CuDNN convolution, if you turn that off, they should be equivalent if you do not use dropout
also you need to fix seed for python, numpy and mxnet
Try to allow the function take an additional pointer, then you can use that additional pointer to hold the closure object, see the way updater is dealt

I tried python mnist gpu case, it works well. So I think my cuda and mxnet build are well made. 

Then I went into R. After checked Sys.getEnv, the cuda folder is not in the list. Then I do Sys.setEnv, works.

@piiswrong I'm not sure whether I misunderstand what you meant by 'the call back takes more than 1 argument', since it does take two argument (const char\* and void*) and I tested it by hand which worked. Moreover, monitor_callback_ is std::function, and what SetMonitorCallback in graph_executor.h used to do is simply converting C func PTR to std::function implicitly using std::function::operator=
And I didn't change the exposed c api, it is still pure C function ptr.

@tqchen Sorry I don't understand how to hold an java object by an additional pointer in pure c function, (this jobject will not be passed as an argument when executor calls back). KVStore::updater is using std::function, and it is the easiest way to bind an object so far I see. 
Let me know if I missed anything, thank you.

@chandlerz In my opinion, `inception-bn` comes from Google's paper [Batch Normalization](http://arxiv.org/abs/1502.03167) and `inception-bn-full` is the network dmlc modified to train the full ImageNet dataset.

@tqchen I reviewed c api again. I think I got what you mean. Did you suggest that, instead of invoking set_updater directly, we can pass jobject to c_api::MXKVStoreSetUpdater as the last argument ?

So by using this approach, besides changing SetMonitorCallback in executor.h (change argument type), we have to change MXExecutorSetMonitorCallback in c_api.h as well, add an additional pointer to its arguments, right?
if you want to use atlas, you need to set USE_BLAS = atlas
@antinucleon This looks like a bug in CSVIter's parsing.
I don't want to use atlas. I'd like to use blas, and had it working before.
try adding -L/usr/lib64 to ldflags?

That doesn't seem to work. I get the same error. When I switch to USE_BLAS = atlas, I get the following:

```
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lcblas
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make: *** [lib/libmxnet.so] Error 1
```
This error with atlas should be easier to fix. Just add add path to your atlas folder to LDFLAGS.
Things work now using atlas. Perhaps I never got it to work with blas. Thanks for the help!
This is expected behavior. You cannot load a numpyop. Instead, you can recreate the symbol and the model, then init the parameters by loading with with mx.initializer.Load
@wangg12 Thank you for your reply. I still haven't got the points yet.

Update the resnet-small example, there are differences to the paper:
- 1*1 convolution operators are used for increasing dimensions.
-  This is a small residual net consists of 52 layers.
- Data augmentations are using mxnet default options include center crop (instead of random crop) and random mirror, **no** paddings on raw image data and the input image size is 28×28(instead of 32×32).
- Hyper parameters, this code is using initial lr=0.01, wd=0.00001. 

Running this example by
`python train_cifar10.py --network=resnet-small --lr=0.01 --lr-factor=0.1 --lr-factor-epoch=20 --num-epochs=30` 
I get a final train accuracy about 91.75% and test accuracy about 84.30%.

ps: I think  `magnitude` should be 2.0 when using kaiming weight init method,  because `Var[w_l]==2/n_l`, however when I set magnitude=2, the net don't converge.
@wangg12 you are right, I have updated the example code.
@javelinjs Yes, the object pointer is passed as updater_handle

Clearly, what I did before was the wrong way to do it. **My post above can be disregarded** but may be helpful for others that don't have a clue of what they're doing with the installation :')

So I've started over again.

This time I realised I first have to get everything from https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet , in which the R-package folder exists.

### Following instructions from @thirdwing

(1) I created the folder 'R-package/inst/libs/x64'

(2) In this folder, I copied all .dll files I think I need from [20151228_win64_gpu.7z](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases/download/20151228/20151228_win64_gpu.7z)

To be precise, from the file I linked I copied all .dll files from:
- nocudnn/3rdparty/cudart
- nocudnn/3rdparty/cudnn/bin (cudnn64_70.dll)
- nocudnn/3rdparty/openblas/bin
- nocudnn/3rdparty/vc
- nocudnn/3rdparty/lib

(3) "create the folder R-package/inst/include and copy all header files into it. Just like what we do in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/Makefile#L190-L192"

I did what you said here- and I end up with 3 subfolders in `R-package/inst/nclude/`, namely `/dmlc`, `/mshadow` and `mxnet`.

(4) Now I run, `R CMD INSTALL R-package`

### Result from installing

(Note that I realised I at least had to update R since my last post)
When I run `R CMD INSTALL R-package`, I get this output:

`* installing to library 'D:/Program files/R-3.2.3/library/mxnet'`
`* installing *source* package 'mxnet' ...`
`**libs`

`*** arch -i386`
`make: Nothing to be done for`all'.`
`installing to D:/Program files/R-3.2.3/library/mxnet/libs/i386`

`*** arch -x64`
`make: Nothing to be done for 'all'.`
`installing to D:/Program files/R-3.2.3/library/mxnet/libs/x64`

`** R`
`** demo`
`** inst`
`** preparing package for lazy loading`
`** help`
`*** installing help indices`
`** building package indices`
`** installing vignettes`
`** testing if installed package can be loaded`
`*** arch - i386`
`Error : .onLoad failed in loadNamespace() for 'mxnet', details:`
`call: library.dynam("libmxnet", pkgname, libname, local = FALSE)`
`error: DLL 'libmxnet' not found: maybe not installed for this architecture?`
`Error: loading failed`
`Execution halted`

`*** arch - x64`
`Error: loading failed for 'i386'`
`* removing 'D:/Program files/R-3.2.3/library/mxnet'`

### What I tried to do to fix it

So I googled a bit based on the error I got:
`Error : .onLoad failed in loadNamespace() for 'mxnet', details:`
`call: library.dynam("libmxnet", pkgname, libname, local = FALSE)`
`error: DLL 'libmxnet' not found: maybe not installed for this architecture?`

And I checked if I already had an installation of mxnet , which I don't. (I uninstalled the CPU-version)
And, I checked if the `libmxnet.dll` file was present in `R-package/inst/libs/x64', and it is.

Also, I am wondering why it tries to do anything with 'i386' in the first place..

I hope somebody can help me solve the last few steps, because I do think I am close to getting it.

The paper is only a compressor, not an accelerator.
Will push an accelerator soon, according to our test on VGG it can accelerate at least twice without any loss of accuracy.
Will it affect the performance significantly?
Great job!. Seems the ICML version of BN overlooked the second term of delta_mu. Thank you.
why me code style is so strange!

Got it! I Copied too much code and provide_data and provide_label where fixed at batchsize 1.
It works now !

I tried the same segmentation idea with caffe and cxxnet with disappointing results without finding out why. With mxnet I could write my own iterator and solver and really (easily) look what was going on in the net. Now I got it working in 2 days. I'm hooked!

Great stuff !

@tqchen Could you take a look again?

The problem is this line here:
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/train_model.py#L47
the string -1 does not trigger the gpu case.

The mnist example has no default listed for gpu (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/train_mnist.py#L13) and thus is run with the cpu.

The cifar example does have a default given. (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/train_cifar10.py#L12). To make it run on a cpu you can just remove the default="0" line.
try make clean
Mostly goes to saving memory

I think they had the order wrong: decision forests are good at handling discrete data. Putting a DNN under them takes that away and it's just another DNN ensemble. You should put DNNs on top of decision forests.

If I pass in mx.metric.RMSE to eval_metric in fit, I get the following error:

```
INFO:root:Start training with [gpu(0), gpu(1), gpu(2), gpu(3)]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "ananas.py", line 75, in <module>
    main()
  File "ananas.py", line 68, in main
    batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size)
  File "/net/noble/vol1/home/jmschr/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg/mxnet/model.py", line 655, in fit
    logger=logger, work_load_list=work_load_list, monitor=monitor)
  File "/net/noble/vol1/home/jmschr/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg/mxnet/model.py", line 241, in _train_multi_device
    eval_metric.update(data_batch.label, executor_manager.cpu_output_arrays)
  File "/net/noble/vol1/home/jmschr/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg/mxnet/metric.py", line 108, in update
    self.sum_metric += self._feval(label, pred)
TypeError: __init__() takes exactly 1 argument (3 given)
```

Same if I pass in mx.metric.MAE. This error is coming from CustomMetric which doesn't make sense to me. Here is my full code:

```
def Convolution( data, num_filter, kernel, stride=(1,1), pad=(0,0), name=None, suffix='' ):
    """Create a convolution layer with batch normalization and relu activations."""

    conv = mx.symbol.Convolution( data=data, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=kernel, stride=stride, pad=pad, name='conv_{}{}'.format( name, suffix ) )
    bn = mx.symbol.BatchNorm( data=conv, name='bn_{}{}'.format( name, suffix ) )
    act = mx.symbol.Activation( data=bn, act_type='relu', name='relu_{}{}'.format( name, suffix ) )
    return act

def InnerProduct( data, num_hidden, name=None, suffix='', weight=None, bias=None ):
    """Create an inner product layer with ReLU activations."""

    ip = mx.symbol.FullyConnected( data=data, num_hidden=num_hidden )
    act = mx.symbol.LeakyReLU( data=ip, act_type='prelu', name="relu_{}{}".format( name, suffix ) )
    return act


def main():
    X_train = numpy.load( '../data/X_train.npy' )
    y_train = numpy.load( '../data/y_train.npy' )

    X_test = numpy.load( '../data/X_test.npy' )
    y_test = numpy.load( '../data/y_test.npy' )

    print X_train.shape
    print y_train.shape
    print y_train.max()

    batch_size = 256

    sequence = mx.symbol.Variable( name='data' )
    conv1 = Convolution( sequence, 16, (5, 4), stride=(1, 1), name="conv1" )
    conv2 = Convolution( conv1, 16, (5, 1), stride=(1, 1), name="conv2" )
    conv3 = Convolution( conv2, 32, (5, 1), stride=(1, 1), name="conv3" )

    mp = mx.symbol.Pooling( conv3, kernel=(110, 1), pool_type='max', name="mp" )
    flatten = mx.symbol.Flatten( mp )

    ip1 = InnerProduct( flatten, 256, name="ip1" )
    ip2 = InnerProduct( ip1, 256, name="ip2" )
    ip3 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected( data=ip2, num_hidden=1, name="y" )

    y = mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput( data=ip3, name="y" )

    train_data  = mx.io.NDArrayIter( X_train, label={ 'y_label' : y_train }, batch_size=batch_size )
    eval_data   = mx.io.NDArrayIter( X_test,  label={ 'y_label' : y_test }, batch_size=batch_size )

    model = mx.model.FeedForward( ctx=[ mx.gpu(0), mx.gpu(1), mx.gpu(2), mx.gpu(3) ], 
                                  symbol=y,
                                  num_epoch=2,
                                  learning_rate=0.00001,
                                  wd=0.1,
                                  optimizer='adam',
                                )
    model.fit( X=train_data, 
               eval_data=eval_data, 
               eval_metric=mx.metric.RMSE,
               batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size)
             )
```
I can't find where LinearRegressionOutput or SoftmaxOutput are in the python repo. Can someone point me in that direction so I can fully understand how they work?
you can use `--gpus None`, but i guess cpu could be very slow since we used a more complex model for cifar10 comparing to mnist
try `make clean_all` and then make which will rebuilt ps-lite
@wangg12 is right, `-full` means the full imagenet dataset, see an example http://dmlc.ml/mxnet/2015/10/27/training-deep-net-on-14-million-images.html

WaitToRead waits until the result of the ndarray is available. This takes a long time because all the computation are asynchronize, and it will block until the computation sequence that get to the result is available

Why is it using accuracy as the metric if I'm using a LinearRegressionOutput? Is it calculating the gradient using MSE but then using a secondary accuracy metric? How do I get it to display a more appropriate metric?
Which GCC version are you using? When I was using keras I know I get errors which looked like this because I was using the wrong version (GCC was too recent).
Currently the default metric do not come together with the objective used, so metric need to be manually specified in the fit method. We can however, support some automatic decision of metric
The problem is we cannot distinguish which are data and which are not, so best way is still ask user to specify which gradient to compute via dict in simple bind
Thanks

@winstywang , i update the example by:
1. fix the cut_off_size bug of data.py
2. change ElementWiseSum to directly "+" symbol.
3. add the h_w parameter for Crop Operator, and this can be used for general cropping operator.
4. fix/add some descriptions.
5. update the new symbol in [yun.baidu](http://pan.baidu.com/s/1bgz4PC) for use.

ps, thought i add the h_w for explicitly set the height and width for crop, but i also retain the use of "crop_like" symbol for height and width when corpping. the reason is that even if we crop the input data with the same size, we should also need to manually calculator the crop h_w in some other place, just like in fcn16s and fcn8s , https://github.com/tornadomeet/mxnet/blob/b8b9700fcdb1d7fb4c79a3d271da178639453b8a/example/fcn-xs/symbol_fcnxs.py#L179 and https://github.com/tornadomeet/mxnet/blob/b8b9700fcdb1d7fb4c79a3d271da178639453b8a/example/fcn-xs/symbol_fcnxs.py#L186 , we should know the size of score_pool4c and score_pool3c, so if some hyper-parameter of cnn structure is changed, like the stride, pad... then we should manually calculator the size again, so the crop_like symbol is used for auto calculate the crop_size without consider the change of paramter. 
what do you think about this?
@mavenlin done
fixed
Thank you

@mli Thank you! The problem has been solved.
@piiswrong 'make clean_all' solved the problem.

Two more comments @tornadomeet 
In this application, using crop_like is proper. What I mean is that in implementation of new op, we had better make it more general. Current implementation is good.

After fixing these two issues, we can merge in this PR, though some further efforts are needed to make it better, including but not limited to:

1) Using batch for training.
2) Multi-GPU support
3) Add evaluation on VOC

I'm new to this framework and I'm wondering if there is any particular reason why optimizers are written in python/R/Julia? Other than that thanks for the great work!

I'd like to think that having them in C++ would improve code reuse, as binding languages wouldn't have to reimplement the optimizers again and again, just provide access to the C++ implementation. This could also improve performance (Try MNIST with 'sgd' and 'ccsgd').
The downside I see for having all optimizers in C++, would be that these would be harder to write, debug and maintain. (see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/optimizer/sgd-inl.h vs https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/optimizer.py#L129).

Also, if anyone is interested in a C++ implementation of RMSProp 'ccrmsprop'. I can create a PR from my branch: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/compare/master...recastrodiaz:ccrmsprop
:+1: For writing a base set of optimizers in C++.  It'd be really nice to not have to figure out how to re-implement all the cool python stuff in R...

This currently cannot be done in mxnet. you need to resize the network on each batch which is a missing feature.
One workaround is to bind with maximum possible instances and zero pad. then ignore extra padded examples when calculating loss.
It should be `metric.RMSE()`, with function invokation to create metric object, sorry for the confusion

Please have a look at #1085

The answer here is to update the `ADD_CFLAGS` variable in make/osx.mk with a path to your current XCode installation. Is there a way to fill this in by default by inspecting a user's XCode path? On my machine the edit to osx.mk that solved my problem was: 

`ADD_CFLAGS = -isysroot /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.11.sdk -mmacosx-version-min=10.11`

I am now experiencing an error relating to the line `#include <cblas.h>` which I am guessing can also be fixed by updating flags, perhaps add `LD_FLAGS`. Any input welcome.
